title: U.K. Regulator Tells Companies to Improve Financial Disclosures
text:
A U.K. regulator said British companies need to improve the quality of financial disclosures in their annual reports.

British companies need to improve the quality of financial disclosures in their annual reports following the introduction of two new accounting standards, the U.K. Financial Reporting Council said in a review released Thursday.

The country’s regulator for accounting and auditing reviewed the annual reports of 65 British companies and analyzed the application of new rules governing the accounting of revenue recognition and financial instruments as well as of an existing rule on the impairment of nonfinancial assets.

“There is considerable scope for companies to improve the quality of their disclosures which will be a focus of future reviews in the early years of application of the new standards,” the council said in a statement.

Newsletter Sign-up Companies booking revenue and cash flows from contracts with customers under International Financial Reporting Standard 15—a rule that took effect for reporting periods beginning on or after Jan. 1, 2018—should improve the descriptions of their accounting policies and provide more detailed information about the judgments affecting the amount and timing of revenue recognized, the FRC said. Firms classifying and measuring their financial assets and liabilities under IFRS 9, a new rule that also took effect for reporting periods starting on or after Jan. 1, 2018, were told by the FRC to provide more detail on credit risks. Companies applying IAS 36, a standard on how to impair assets, could provide more information around their judgments and key assumptions, the FRC said. Thursday’s findings come amid growing concerns about the application of key accounting standards by British companies and the audit of financial statements by large audit firms. Regulators and lawmakers have suggested various changes to the rules governing the U.K. accounting and audit industry, but the government has yet to respond to these proposals. As part of the changes, the FRC’s former leadership team consisting of Chairman Win Bischoff and Chief Executive Stephen Haddrill has stepped down. They were replaced Tuesday by Chairman Simon Dingemans, the former finance chief of pharmaceuticals company GlaxoSmithKline PLC, and Chief Executive Jon Thompson, who previously ran the U.K.’s tax office. The FRC will become part of a new regulatory body called the Audit, Reporting and Governance Authority. Write to Nina Trentmann at Nina.Trentmann@wsj.com
